column6: Approach to stakeholder engagement
column13: Woodside's First Nations Advisory Group Roundtable is vital for meaningful dialogue and collaboration with Indigenous communities. By actively engaging with First Nations representatives, Woodside seeks to incorporate Indigenous perspectives and priorities into project planning and decision-making processes. This commitment fosters mutual respect, understanding, and sustainable partnerships for all stakeholders.

column6: Approach to stakeholder engagement
column13: Woodside's Cultural Heritage Management Procedure exemplifies the company's dedication to respecting and preserving cultural heritage. By engaging with Indigenous groups and heritage experts, Woodside ensures that cultural sites are identified, protected, and respectfully managed throughout project lifecycles. This collaborative approach fosters trust, honours cultural diversity, and promotes sustainable development practices.

column6: Approach to stakeholder engagement
column13: Woodside's Heritage Research initiative is a proactive engagement effort aimed at understanding and respecting the historical significance of project areas. Through comprehensive research and consultation with local communities and heritage experts, Woodside identifies and preserves cultural heritage sites. By incorporating this knowledge into project planning, Woodside demonstrates its commitment to responsible development that honours and protects cultural heritage.

column6: Approach to stakeholder engagement
column13: Woodside's Investor Briefings are a crucial engagement platform, fostering transparency and communication with shareholders and stakeholders. These briefings provide insights into the company's strategic direction, financial performance, and critical initiatives, enabling stakeholders to make informed decisions. By maintaining open dialogue and addressing investor inquiries, Woodside builds trust and accountability, enhancing relationships with its investor community.

column6: Approach to stakeholder engagement
column13: The Local Content Manager at Woodside fosters collaboration and economic growth within local communities. By facilitating partnerships with local businesses and suppliers, they ensure that Woodside's operations contribute positively to regional development. Through their efforts, the Local Content Manager strengthens relationships, promotes job creation, and maximises the benefits of Woodside's presence in its operations areas.

column6: Approach to stakeholder engagement
column13: Gnaala Karla Booja's engagement at Woodside exemplifies the company's commitment to meaningful collaboration with Indigenous communities. Through ongoing dialogue and partnership, Woodside respects and incorporates Gnaala Karla Pooja's perspectives into its operations, fostering mutual understanding and trust. Woodside aims to create shared value and promote sustainable development in its operating regions by honouring cultural heritage and supporting community initiatives.

column6: Collective bargaining agreements
column7: Woodside maintains an open and collaborative working relationship with its global workforce. As of 31 December 2023, 202 employees (representing 4.4% of our total workforce) were covered by collective bargaining agreements. All other employees' working conditions and terms of employment are based on industry conditions determined by the relevant laws and regulations in their respective jurisdictions.

column6: Process to determine material topics
column7: The materiality assessment process involves a study by internal subject matter experts drawing from various internal and external inputs, including from our Executive Leadership Team and Directors. We also continue to monitor developments, trends, and stakeholder views throughout the year. Our approach seeks to understand the topics relevant to our business activities and stakeholders.\t

column6: List of material topics
column7: Woodside's material topics include climate, safety and well-being, environment and biodiversity, and the First National Cultural Engagement Plan.

column6: Management of material topics
Direct economic value generated and distributed
column7: Woodside's net profit after tax FY23 was AUSD 1.7 billion.

column6: Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
column7: Woodside has actively hedged its balance sheet position against the commodity cycle and green transition trend through the Capital Management Framework.

column6: Defined benefit plan obligations and other retirement plans
column7: All Group employees are entitled to benefits on retirement, disability, or death from the Group's retirement plans. The Group operates several pension schemes worldwide. Employees entitled to defined contribution schemes receive fixed contributions from Group companies, and the Group's legal or constructive obligation is limited to these contributions.

column6: Financial assistance received from government
Ratios of standard entry level wage by gender compared to local minimum wage
column7: At Woodside, men and women are paid equally for the same job based on skills, responsibilities and performance. FY23 median total remuneration by gender was 30.2%.

The Indigenous Capability Strategy Advisor helps Woodside create a more inclusive and culturally diverse workforce by championing diversity and fostering meaningful partnerships.

column8: Indigenous Cultural Learning for Leaders program
column13: The Indigenous Cultural Learning for Leaders program at Woodside underscores the company's dedication to cultural awareness and respect. By providing leaders with immersive learning experiences and insights into Indigenous cultures, the program fosters greater understanding and appreciation within the organisation. column6: Infrastructure investments and services supported
Significant indirect economic impacts
column7: Woodside's total social contribution spent globally in FY23 was AUSD 33.3 million.

column6: Proportion of spending on local suppliers
column7: In 2023, we spent more than US$7.2 billion on goods and services, with most of the spending occurring in Australia, Senegal, the United States, Germany, and Japan.\t

column6: Operations assessed for risks related to corruption
column7: Woodside's anti-bribery and corruption (ABC) policy staunchly prohibits any form of bribery or corrupt practices within its operations, ensuring integrity and transparency at all levels of business conduct. This policy underscores Woodside's commitment to upholding ethical standards, fostering stakeholder trust, and promoting fair business practices worldwide.

column6: Communication and training about anti-corruption policies and procedures
column13: The ABC (Anti-Bribery and Corruption) face-to-face training at Woodside equips employees with crucial skills and knowledge to recognise and combat unethical practices. Through interactive sessions and real-life case studies, participants learn to uphold integrity and comply with anti-corruption laws and regulations. By investing in this training, Woodside reinforces its commitment to ethical conduct, ensuring a culture of transparency and accountability across the organisation.
column20: ABC face-to-face training, anti-bribery and corruption, ABC compliance framework

column6: Confirmed incidents of corruption and actions taken
column7: During 2023, no violations of applicable anti-bribery and corruption laws were recorded in connection with our operations.

column6: Legal actions for anti-competitive behavior, anti-trust, and monopoly practices
Approach to tax
column7: Woodside participates in the Australian Board of Taxation's voluntary Tax Transparency Code (TTC). The TTC recommends public disclosure of tax information to increase public confidence in corporate taxpayers' contributions and compliance.

column6: Tax governance, control, and risk management
column7: Woodside's Audit & Risk Committee (A&RC) supports the Woodside Board in meeting its oversight responsibilities on tax matters. The A&RC achieves this through regular engagement with and attendance by the Vice President of Tax at committee meetings and by reviewing policies and practices for managing compliance with tax laws.

column6: Stakeholder engagement and management of concerns related to tax
